abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Participatory Rural
            Investment Project in Bolivia were as follows: outcomes were
            moderately satisfactory, the risk to development outcome was
            moderate, the Bank performance was satisfactory, and the
            Borrower performance was moderately unsatisfactory. Some
            lessons learned included: 1) A demand-driven, market-based
            model of institutional strengthening generates wider social
            capacities, increases the number of suppliers and improves
            local actors' managerial capacities; 2) Restricting the
            participatory planning process to the municipal territory
            may not necessarily be conducive to optimal decision-making;
            3) The coherence between the longer-term municipal
            development plans (PDMs) and the annual operational plans
            (POA) are not necessarily automatic. Concerted efforts are
            needed to guarantee coherence between planning and
            implementation; 4) The complexity of the M&E indicators
            needs to be related to the institutional capacity of the
            user; 5) Outsourcing training services to formal and
            established training institutions, such as universities,
            could result in a more sustainable institutionality for
            supplying these services in the future; 6) Participatory
            demand identification needs to be complemented with solid
            technical inputs in order to ensure adequate ranking of
            development priorities for the communities; 7) The spot
            improvement approach for low-volume rural roads reduces unit
            costs, reduces environmental impacts and has a greater
            likelihood of ensuring year-round access than traditional
            approaches. 8) Reductions in transportation costs across all
            sectors and activities prove that rural roads can be
            justified on the basis of improving access to services
            (health, education, etc.) and not necessarily on the basis
            of production increases; 9) It should not be assumed that
            municipalities will allocate sufficient resources for the
            cost of operation and maintenance of rural infrastructure
            built or rehabilitated with the project; and 10) As the
            experience with "emergency" subprojects showed,
            the subproject cycle can be simplified, identification
            focused on technical aspects and implementation more clearly
            delegated to municipalities.

abstracts.cdata!:
The Participatory Rural Investment
            Project for Bolivia aims to promote economic development of
            rural municipalities and communities through sustainable
            productive investments based on local demand with
            participatory planing processes. There are two components.
            The first, Rural Investments, finances consulting services
            for pre-investment studies, and works, goods, and equipment
            for pre-investment subprojects. It improves access roads and
            builds and rehabilitates bridges, builds small-scale
            irrigation systems; sets up markets and produce storage
            facilities, makes river embankment improvements, provides
            technical assistance to rural producers, and finances
            cultural heritage rehabilitation as well as other minor
            works identified by municipalities and communities. The
            second component, Institutional Strengthening, funds 1)
            technical assistance to municipalities, indigenous
            districts, rural communities and nongovernmental
            organizations in municipal management, participatory
            planning and implementation; 2) formal and non-formal
            training of staff and community participants; and 3)
            consultants, office equipment, vehicles, and operating costs
            for vice-ministries and development funds.

repnme.cdata!:
Bolivia - Participatory Rural Investment
            Project - environmental impact analysis

abstracts.cdata!:
This report is an environmental
            assessment reviewing the environmental screening procedures
            of the Bolivia's Participatory Rural Investment Project
            (FDC), which builds and improves municipal infrastructure;
            and strengthens municipal administration and management with
            community participation. This impact analysis details how
            the screening procedures are being applied, evaluates the
            project's environmental impacts, and suggests
            mitigation measures. Measures include segregation and
            disposal of waste materials at dump sites; construction of
            retaining walls; resort to reforestation to control erosion;
            replacement of the natural vegetal cover and adjacent
            forest; construction of longitudinal drainage crossing
            primary and secondary roads as well as hillsides; control of
            wastewater, runoff, and garbage from the worksite to avoid
            damage to river beds and aquatic life; prevention of oil and
            fuel leaks from machinery and vehicles; synchronized usage
            of machinery and vehicles in order to reduce air emissions;
            relocation of displaced human settlements; management of
            liquid flows to water bodies; and control of solid wastes,
            liquid flows, and gaseous emissions during the
            project's operation.
